header_summary:
Ava Chow announced the availability of Bitcoin Core's latest release candidate, version v28.3rc1, emphasizing its role in the development cycle for testing and feedback, with links to both binaries and source code provided for interested developers ([Bitcoin Core Release](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-28.3/test.rc1/), [GitHub Source](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/tree/v28.3rc1)). Anthony Towns contributed to the conversation by focusing on the nuances of Tapscript v2, proposing clearer naming conventions and additional selector functionalities to enhance Bitcoin's scripting capabilities, and including a reference for further technical exploration ([Delving into Bitcoin](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/contract-level-relative-timelocks-or-lets-talk-about-ancestry-proofs-and-singletons/1353)). Erik Aronesty and fjahr discussed the importance of securing the UTXO set root for efficient synchronization and mitigating network vulnerabilities, respectively, highlighting strategies for enhancing Bitcoin's overall security framework ([UTXO Security](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/CAJowKgLpix4KjzJGKNzR3JpiKLDJKSiuuOdcebCyGJnDuw0wJw@mail.gmail.com/T/#m96412373b0efd17e954d65d9ed50b097d2e2d5be), [Network Vulnerabilities](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/eclipsing-bitcoin-nodes-with-bgp-interception-attacks/1965/8)).

ZmnSCPxj delved into the vulnerabilities of Trusted Execution Environments (TEEs) and proposed a novel storage solution leveraging multiple TEEs for enhanced security against rollback attacks, focusing on the technicalities and benefits of this approach ([Persistent Mutable Storage](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/persisting-mutable-storage-inside-the-t-ee/2029)). Lastly, sindurasaraswathi raised critical points about the security models of threshold systems, suggesting a statistical approach to finding an optimal balance between security and usability, paving the way for future research in threshold signature schemes ([Optimal Threshold Signatures](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/optimal-threshold-signatures-in-bitcoin/2023/4)). Combined, these discussions reflect a continuous effort within the Bitcoin development community to address and improve both the technical and security aspects of the cryptocurrency ecosystem.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 28.3 Release Candidate 1 Available
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core's latest release candidate, v28.3rc1, is now available for download.
- Preliminary release notes detailing changes and improvements are accessible online.
- This update is crucial for developers and the Bitcoin ecosystem, moving towards the official v28.3 release.

recent_posts.title: [0/4] A Bitcoin Scripting Proposal BIP Quartet
recent_posts.summary:
- Rusty Russell's email discusses Tapscript v2's naming and functionality for Bitcoin.
- It proposes new naming conventions and a selector for better script clarity.
- The conversation includes advanced topics like relative timelocks and drivechains.

recent_posts.title: OP_CHECKUTXOSETHASH idea
recent_posts.summary:
- Using the UTXO set root from prior intervals enhances security and lightweight sync.
- Incremental hashing and data structures like Merkleized trees improve efficiency.
- This method focuses updates on changed UTXOs, making the process faster and less resource-intensive.

recent_posts.title: Eclipsing Bitcoin Nodes with BGP Interception Attacks
recent_posts.summary:
- The email discusses identifying network vulnerabilities through fingerprinting and mapping techniques.
- It emphasizes enhancing security by understanding these weaknesses and countering attacker tactics.
- Initiatives for educating Bitcoin and Lightning Network operators on mitigating threats are proposed, including developing tools.

recent_posts.title: Persisting Mutable Storage Inside The "T"EE
recent_posts.summary:
- The exploration of TEEs highlights a serious vulnerability to rollback attacks, particularly in Bitcoin applications.
- A novel strategy using multiple TEEs for secure, persistent storage through strategic distribution and encryption is proposed.
- This approach enhances data security and resilience, offering a solution against the inherent vulnerabilities of TEEs.

recent_posts.title: Optimal Threshold Signatures in Bitcoin
recent_posts.summary:
- The discussion addresses the intertwined probabilities of legitimate user access and unauthorized access in threshold systems.
- It mentions the simplification of treating these probabilities as independent for ease of current analysis.
- The email highlights the need for statistical analysis to find an optimal threshold in signature schemes, noting a research gap.

authors: [BIP Proposal] Mempool Validation and Relay Policies via User-Defined Scripts Aiden McClelland
active_posts.summary:
- Aiden McClelland proposes a BIP for a modular mempool/relay policy on GitHub.
- McClelland develops this BIP with QuickJS, facing challenges due to a C++ hiatus.
- The proposal aims to unify Bitcoin community views with a flexible relay policy framework.

active_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] Limit ScriptPubkey Size >= 520 Bytes Consensus.
active_posts.summary:
- Brandon Black proposes a Bitcoin soft fork to limit ScriptPubkey size for security.
- The change targets minimal, existing uses to boost scalability and prevent DoS attacks.
- It addresses future network needs while acknowledging potential objections and complexities.

active_posts.title: On (in)ability to embed data into Schnorr
active_posts.summary:
- AdamISZ examines embedding data in Schnorr signatures, questioning the feasibility without compromising security.
- The analysis concludes that data embedding risks revealing the private key, undermining UTXO security.
- Invites critique on his research, accessible on GitHub, to explore cryptographic implications on blockchain privacy and security.

active_posts.title: Changes to BIP-360 - Pay to Quantum Resistant Hash (P2QRH)
active_posts.summary:
- BIP-360 enhancements target quantum attack resilience, transitioning P2QRH to script-only P2TR.
- Implementation simplifies while enhancing security against potential quantum computing attacks.
- Proposes a flexible framework for integrating Post-Quantum signature verification without immediate specification commitments.

active_posts.title: Where does the 33.33% threshold for selfish mining come from?
active_posts.summary:
- Selfish mining strategy aims to surpass fair share of blockchain contributions, exploiting block revelations.
- Profitability thresholds for selfish mining hinge on hashrate control and block propagation speed.
- Theoretical and simulated analyses reveal profitability beyond one-third network hashrate, between 36% and 37%.

active_posts.title: Response to Pieter Wuille's StackExchange Answer Re: Nuking the Opreturn Filter
active_posts.summary:
- The email discusses Bitcoin fee estimation's unreliability due to unpredictable miner actions and block timings.
- It criticizes efforts to standardize mempools for predicting miner behavior, highlighting risks of centralization.
- The author advocates for adapting to Bitcoin's inherent uncertainties with broader network-wide heuristics.

today_in_history_posts.title: Request: OP_CHECKTXOUTSCRIPTHASHVERIFY
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- A new Bitcoin opcode, OP_CHECKTXOUTSCRIPTHASHVERIFY, is proposed to enforce predefined transaction outputs.
- It aims to enhance security by allowing transactions only if matched with the NextRedeemScript, thwarting unauthorized spending.
- Despite potential defense improvements, compromised keys and privacy concerns pose remaining challenges.

today_in_history_posts.title: RFC: simplifications and suggestions on open/accept limits.
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Gert-Jaap Glasbergen opposes removing htlc_minimum_msat to prevent trimmed HTLCs.
- He suggests adjustments like transaction_min_msat_multiple and minimum_depth variability per chain.
- Rusty Russell supports chain-specific minimum_depth but critiques the sub-1000 msat opt-out proposal.

today_in_history_posts.title: Thoughts on scaling and consensus changes (2023)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin aims to support 1 billion weekly users via 50,000 off-chain "bitcoin banks."- Off-chain transactions may balance cost and security, avoiding blockchain's high fees.
- Enhancing Bitcoin's scalability requires tools for safe operation and efficient Layer 1 exits.
